chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Contraindications and cautions
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not prescribe amoxicillin to people with:
    • True penicillin hypersensitivity. Note: gastrointestinal adverse effects alone (such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhoea) do not constitute an allergy to penicillin. See the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information.
    • A history of penicillin-associated hepatic dysfunction.
  • Prescribe amoxicillin with caution to people with:
    • Hypersensitivity to cephalosporins.
    • Acute or chronic lymphocytic leukaemia — increased risk of erythematous rashes.
    • Glandular fever — erythematous rashes common.
    • Hepatic impairment.
    • Renal impairment — risk of crystalluria with high doses.

[Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]

Possible adverse effects of amoxicillin include:

  • Anaphylaxis (rare). See the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information.
  • Diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting, and skin rash. Note: severe diarrhoea during or after treatment with antibiotics may be a sign of antibiotic-associated colitis (pseudomembranous colitis). See the CKS topic on Diarrhoea - antibiotic associated for more information.
  • Crystalluria, dizziness, hyperkinesia, hypersensitivity vasculitis, and mucocutaneous candidiasis.

[Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Drug interactions
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Possible drug interactions with amoxicillin include:

  • Allopurinol — allopurinol increases the risk of skin rash when given with amoxicillin.
  • Anticoagulants (for example warfarin) — amoxicillin potentially alters the anticoagulant effect of warfarin. The manufacturer advises to monitor the international normalized ratio (INR) and adjust the dose of warfarin accordingly.
    • Advise people taking warfarin to seek immediate medical advice if they experience spontaneous bleeding, and the bleeding does not stop or recurs.
  • Methotrexate — amoxicillin may increase the risk of toxicity when given with methotrexate.
    • Monitor levels of methotrexate closely. One recommendation is to carry out twice weekly platelet and white cell counts for 2 weeks initially, with the measurement of methotrexate levels if toxicity is suspected.
  • Oral hormonal contraception — additional contraceptive precautions are not required during or after courses of penicillins. However, advise women on the importance of correct contraceptive practice if they experience vomiting or diarrhoea. See the CKS topics on Contraception - combined hormonal methods and Contraception - progestogen-only methods for more information.

[Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Pregnancy and breastfeeding
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Pregnancy

  • Penicillins are the antibiotics of choice in pregnancy and can safely be used in the usual doses [Schaefer, 2015].
  • The British National Formulary (BNF) states that penicillins are not known to be harmful in pregnancy [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]. 
  • The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) states the majority of available data show no increased risk of congenital malformation, miscarriage, intrauterine death, low birth weight, preterm delivery, or neonatal complications following maternal exposure to therapeutic doses of penicillins [UKTIS, 2017].

Breastfeeding

  • Penicillins are one of the antibiotics of choice in breastfeeding women [Schaefer, 2015].
  • The British National Formulary (BNF) states that only trace amounts of penicillins are found in breast milk [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].
